awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Effect of the matrix on extinction risk: a large scale experiment at Wog Wog
awd_abstract_narration:
Global habitat loss accounts for most biodiversity loss. A critical consequence of this loss is that the only remnants of many ecosystems are small fragments of once continuous habitat, and so the fate of biodiversity, globally, depends on the survival of species in fragments of habitat. Therefore, understanding the fate of species in habitat fragments is imperative. Experimental studies of extinction are extremely rare outside of the laboratory. Thus, long term and large scale habitat fragmentation experiments provide real world understanding of extinction that cannot be uncovered in any other way. The Wog Wog experiment in southeastern Australia is the longest running, large scale experiment in temperate forest, fragmented since 1987. The experiment has provided major insights about which kinds of species are at greatest risk of extinction when their habitat is fragmented. The site is composed of original native eucalypt forest fragments now set within managed commercial pine plantation. These commercial pines are scheduled to be harvested, creating an unprecedented opportunity to discover, in an experimental setting, how extinction risk changes when fragments are re-fragmented, something that occurs commonly in practice. The researchers will determine how re-fragmentation impacts the extinction risk of species on fragments through changes to the environment and the ecosystem function of fragments. 

Many university students will only take one science class, and often that class is Introductory Biology. Dr. Davies co-teaches 1400 Introductory Biology students every year and so has a great opportunity to inspire and increase STEM participation. She will transform the teaching of her large undergraduate biology class by focusing learning around her research at Wog Wog by: 1) focusing on established learning goals, developing mini case studies around video shot by graduate students in the field, and 2) bringing an undergraduate into the field every year to collect habitat structure data through digital photos that will be analysed by the whole class, and used by the PI to model changes to the environment. Dr. Davies hypothesizes that having real-world, real-time biology embedded in class will increase engagement and learning gains.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
We built a broad understanding of the effects of habitat fragmentation on biodiversity. We worked within a habitat fragmentation experiment in southeastern Australia that was established by CSIRO in 1985. We studied impacts on biodiversity in native eucalypt forest fragments within a pine plantation matrix decades after habitat fragmentation.

1. We provide the first large-scale and long-term experimental evidence that species traits that predicted extinction risk seven years after habitat fragmentation continue to predict extinction risk 27 years (generations) after fragmentation. These traits were: high trophic level, isolation on fragments, and rarity. Critically, these traits predicted extinction risk in the fragmented landscape even though the larger beetle community was not negatively impacted by fragmentation in the long term. Instead, for the broader beetle community (~ 700 species), we detected shifting responses so that a species' response in matrix habitat predicted its response in habitat fragments. Some beetle species were negatively impacted early in the experiment and later recovered, while others were not initially impacted but in later years declined in abundance. Over the experiment, the pine plantation matrix grew from saplings to mature trees. Our trait result means that management can confidently target species with traits linked to stochastic extinction risk, in this case, rarity, being isolated on fragments, and high trophic level, as being most at risk in fragmented landscapes.

2. Within the beetle community (~ 700 species), we discovered that beetle species? responses in habitat fragments were predicted by their response in the matrix with a log-response ratio of about 0.5. Within a given species in a given year, declines in abundance in the matrix predict declines in abundance in fragments, while increases in abundance in the matrix predict increases in abundance in fragments. This same predictability in response ratio was present in a 30-year time series of an important and abundant amphipod detritivore.

3. Focusing on an important group of predatory beetles, the carabids (45 species), we found that the total abundance of all carabids, species richness, and the occurrence of six species declined in the short term in the fragments but increased over the long term. The occurrence of three species declined initially and continued to decline, whilst another species was positively affected initially but decreased in the long term. Species? responses to the matrix that surrounds the fragments strongly predicted both the direction (increase/decline in occurrence) and the magnitude of their responses to fragmentation. Additionally, species? responses to the matrix were predicted by their preferences for different types of native habitat (open vs. shaded).

4. Multiple lines of evidence from stable isotope studies within the experiment found that habitat fragmentation did not result in the degradation of food webs over 30 years. These studies focused on funnel-web spiders, skinks, and scorpions.

5. Habitat fragmentation dismantled a parasite network seven years after fragmentation. By 27 years after fragmentation, while the abundances of the host species (an amphipod and skink) that make up the parasite network have recovered, a nematode parasite has not recovered in habitat fragments. The nematode parasite persisted in the continuous forest controls.

6. Habitat fragmentation caused body size reductions in a skink species in the first five years following fragmentation compared to skink populations in continuous forest. Body size was negatively correlated with temperature. In later years of the experiment, body size in fragments and the continuous forest was not different as the pine plantation matrix matured and buffered temperatures in the matrix and habitat fragments.

7. Two critical ant species were not initially impacted by habitat fragmentation but by 23 years after fragmentation had declined in fragments compared to continuous forest.

8. Within the ant community (~ 80 species), fragmentation increased the role of dispersal in the assembly of communities in small and medium fragments (23 years after fragmentation) while at the same time increasing the role of the environment in the assembly of communities in large fragments.

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Kendi F Davies
